Chieh Huang discusses business.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

OCTOBER 30, 2017

SPEAKERS: CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG HOST: Now lawyers of Facebook, Google, and Twitter will appear on Capitol Hill tomorrow to answer questions about Russian meddling in the U.S. presidential election. Amazon is not part of that probe. But increasing scrutiny of the tech industry in Washington could raise antitrust questions for the e-commerce giant.

Joining us now for more insight is Chieh Huang. He is the CEO and founder of Boxed. Great to have you in New York.

CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED: Thank you for having me back.

CHATTERLEY: So what do you think about this? Do you think there needs to be more regulatory oversight of these big tech firms? We'll talk about before we dig down into your business.

HUANG: Well, it's interesting because I have real view and the view that I want to say now and then it will come and bite me in the butt later on.

(CROSSTALK)

CHATTERLEY: Tell us what you think.

HUANG: But I do think so to a certain extent, right? I think as you're looking at kind of the position of Amazon for example, the fact that they can just put a simple press release out there or file a simple trademark application and have an entire market react with billions of market cap loss, I think there's something to that. And whether that needs to be corrected by the markets in general, whether most folks in the market will eventually just say, you know, there it is more bark than bite.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

HUANG: Or whether that is a legislative action. We will see in the future.

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG HOST: Do you see any kind of evidence that a company like amazon is engaging in anti-competitive behavior?

HUANG: I don't see outside of potentially what they've done in the past with some of the acquisitions, and it's well-documented in Brad's book, "The Everything Store in terms of kind of their past acquisition practices. But in general, currently now, it's really a conundrum because what you would say is that they try to lower prices. They try to inject more competition at the marketplace, yet they have an ability to move markets solely by themselves.

So right now in a vacuum, potentially no. But when you look at the swirl of events and their M.O. kind of in the past and now, TBD.

FU: Right. And right now in fact, about 55 percent of all project searches begin on Amazon which has surpassed Google.

HUANG: Yes.

FU: That's been something that caught a lot of attention, unwanted attention on Amazon. How do you raise your company's profile, Boxed profile in this kind of environment when Amazon dominates?

HUANG: What's really interesting is that, yes, they are dominant but there's still some market share left for the rest of us especially in places like B2B. And so for us Boxed, we ship toilet paper, large-format only anywhere in the U.S. But the reality is a big part of our business is actually business-to-business.

So take for example the green rooms you have in Bloomberg or down in the beautiful atrium here, there are just hundreds of different snacks for everyone here to eat and to enjoy. Certainly the folks who stock that pantry aren't going on Amazon and clicking like SkinnyPop Chips like 400 times, you know? And so I think for us, it is really finding those niches where Amazon is not as strong and really going after it.

CHATTERLEY: You know, it's interesting, I read something that you'd said about actually some of your best customers and what you called the bread basket regions of American, populations with 50,000 people, maybe even less at times to. Just to go back to exactly to what you were saying there, do you think they're insulated from the likes of Amazon because logistically they don't really care about going to those regions?

HUANG: To a certain extent, but it -- to your guys' point before, it just offers more opportunity for folks like us because there is a quite a lot of opportunity out there, whether it's in the city or especially out in those rural areas that you mentioned because if you look at our business for example, there's 30 million folks in the U.S. that don't live within 30 minutes drive of a Costco.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

HUANG: And so those folks, it's -- whether they like Costco or not, it doesn't even matter because that brand is ubiquitous, the locations are not. And so that is how, Scarlet, to your point, that's how we've been able to grow so quickly. We went from $40,000 in sales in 2014 in my garage and last year trailing cleared over nine figures in about 36 months span. So absolutely, there is opportunity but you can't take your eye off Amazon.

FU: Chieh, you borrowed a lot from Amazon when you built out our company Boxed. What do you think you do better than Amazon now as a result? What have you adapted better at?

HUANG: It's interesting. So I feel like we have this really good ability to focus on our customer. And so our customer wants wholesale, right? And it's really difficult because Amazon is the everything store and they want to be everything for everyone. And so for us as entrepreneurs, it is really tough when you get a single person living in a 300 foot -- square foot apartment in the Upper East Side and says, you know, Boxed isn't for me. For us to really admit that it isn't for you and that it's solely for large families and for folks who want to stock up on something, that's been really difficult for us to --

FU: Interesting.

HUANG: -- concentrate on. But i feel like we do wholesale better than Amazon partly because as a wholesaler, we can sell different items and different pack sizes that Amazon usually can't get their hands on.

CHATTERLEY: You know, I want to ask you about automation. You have to be really quick because we're running out of time. But you've automated your warehouses and actually not lost any employees as a result. Is that sustainable if you scale that up?

HUANG: I think it is sustainable. I think the reality is folks will need to be able to kind of work with those robotics in order to keep those positions. So for us, we didn't go and layoff anyone solely because of automation.

CHATTERLEY: But you retrained.

HUANG: We retrain them. And now we feel like their ability to have earning power over their career is a lot better.

FU: Chieh Huang, the CEO and Founder and Boxed.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

OCTOBER 30, 2017

SPEAKERS: CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG HOST: Now lawyers of Facebook, Google, and Twitter will appear on Capitol Hill tomorrow to answer questions about Russian meddling in the U.S. presidential election. Amazon is not part of that probe. But increasing scrutiny of the tech industry in Washington could raise antitrust questions for the e-commerce giant.

Joining us now for more insight is Chieh Huang. He is the CEO and founder of Boxed. Great to have you in New York.

CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED: Thank you for having me back.

CHATTERLEY: So what do you think about this? Do you think there needs to be more regulatory oversight of these big tech firms? We'll talk about before we dig down into your business.

HUANG: Well, it's interesting because I have real view and the view that I want to say now and then it will come and bite me in the butt later on.

(CROSSTALK)

CHATTERLEY: Tell us what you think.

HUANG: But I do think so to a certain extent, right? I think as you're looking at kind of the position of Amazon for example, the fact that they can just put a simple press release out there or file a simple trademark application and have an entire market react with billions of market cap loss, I think there's something to that. And whether that needs to be corrected by the markets in general, whether most folks in the market will eventually just say, you know, there it is more bark than bite.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

HUANG: Or whether that is a legislative action. We will see in the future.

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG HOST: Do you see any kind of evidence that a company like amazon is engaging in anti-competitive behavior?

HUANG: I don't see outside of potentially what they've done in the past with some of the acquisitions, and it's well-documented in Brad's book, "The Everything Store in terms of kind of their past acquisition practices. But in general, currently now, it's really a conundrum because what you would say is that they try to lower prices. They try to inject more competition at the marketplace, yet they have an ability to move markets solely by themselves.

So right now in a vacuum, potentially no. But when you look at the swirl of events and their M.O. kind of in the past and now, TBD.

FU: Right. And right now in fact, about 55 percent of all project searches begin on Amazon which has surpassed Google.

HUANG: Yes.

FU: That's been something that caught a lot of attention, unwanted attention on Amazon. How do you raise your company's profile, Boxed profile in this kind of environment when Amazon dominates?

HUANG: What's really interesting is that, yes, they are dominant but there's still some market share left for the rest of us especially in places like B2B. And so for us Boxed, we ship toilet paper, large-format only anywhere in the U.S. But the reality is a big part of our business is actually business-to-business.

So take for example the green rooms you have in Bloomberg or down in the beautiful atrium here, there are just hundreds of different snacks for everyone here to eat and to enjoy. Certainly the folks who stock that pantry aren't going on Amazon and clicking like SkinnyPop Chips like 400 times, you know? And so I think for us, it is really finding those niches where Amazon is not as strong and really going after it.

CHATTERLEY: You know, it's interesting, I read something that you'd said about actually some of your best customers and what you called the bread basket regions of American, populations with 50,000 people, maybe even less at times to. Just to go back to exactly to what you were saying there, do you think they're insulated from the likes of Amazon because logistically they don't really care about going to those regions?

HUANG: To a certain extent, but it -- to your guys' point before, it just offers more opportunity for folks like us because there is a quite a lot of opportunity out there, whether it's in the city or especially out in those rural areas that you mentioned because if you look at our business for example, there's 30 million folks in the U.S. that don't live within 30 minutes drive of a Costco.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

HUANG: And so those folks, it's -- whether they like Costco or not, it doesn't even matter because that brand is ubiquitous, the locations are not. And so that is how, Scarlet, to your point, that's how we've been able to grow so quickly. We went from $40,000 in sales in 2014 in my garage and last year trailing cleared over nine figures in about 36 months span. So absolutely, there is opportunity but you can't take your eye off Amazon.

FU: Chieh, you borrowed a lot from Amazon when you built out our company Boxed. What do you think you do better than Amazon now as a result? What have you adapted better at?

HUANG: It's interesting. So I feel like we have this really good ability to focus on our customer. And so our customer wants wholesale, right? And it's really difficult because Amazon is the everything store and they want to be everything for everyone. And so for us as entrepreneurs, it is really tough when you get a single person living in a 300 foot -- square foot apartment in the Upper East Side and says, you know, Boxed isn't for me. For us to really admit that it isn't for you and that it's solely for large families and for folks who want to stock up on something, that's been really difficult for us to --

FU: Interesting.

HUANG: -- concentrate on. But i feel like we do wholesale better than Amazon partly because as a wholesaler, we can sell different items and different pack sizes that Amazon usually can't get their hands on.

CHATTERLEY: You know, I want to ask you about automation. You have to be really quick because we're running out of time. But you've automated your warehouses and actually not lost any employees as a result. Is that sustainable if you scale that up?

HUANG: I think it is sustainable. I think the reality is folks will need to be able to kind of work with those robotics in order to keep those positions. So for us, we didn't go and layoff anyone solely because of automation.

CHATTERLEY: But you retrained.

HUANG: We retrain them. And now we feel like their ability to have earning power over their career is a lot better.

FU: Chieh Huang, the CEO and Founder and Boxed.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

OCTOBER 30, 2017

SPEAKERS: CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG HOST: Now lawyers of Facebook, Google, and Twitter will appear on Capitol Hill tomorrow to answer questions about Russian meddling in the U.S. presidential election. Amazon is not part of that probe. But increasing scrutiny of the tech industry in Washington could raise antitrust questions for the e-commerce giant.

Joining us now for more insight is Chieh Huang. He is the CEO and founder of Boxed. Great to have you in New York.

CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED: Thank you for having me back.

CHATTERLEY: So what do you think about this? Do you think there needs to be more regulatory oversight of these big tech firms? We'll talk about before we dig down into your business.

HUANG: Well, it's interesting because I have real view and the view that I want to say now and then it will come and bite me in the butt later on.

(CROSSTALK)

CHATTERLEY: Tell us what you think.

HUANG: But I do think so to a certain extent, right? I think as you're looking at kind of the position of Amazon for example, the fact that they can just put a simple press release out there or file a simple trademark application and have an entire market react with billions of market cap loss, I think there's something to that. And whether that needs to be corrected by the markets in general, whether most folks in the market will eventually just say, you know, there it is more bark than bite.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

HUANG: Or whether that is a legislative action. We will see in the future.

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG HOST: Do you see any kind of evidence that a company like amazon is engaging in anti-competitive behavior?

HUANG: I don't see outside of potentially what they've done in the past with some of the acquisitions, and it's well-documented in Brad's book, "The Everything Store in terms of kind of their past acquisition practices. But in general, currently now, it's really a conundrum because what you would say is that they try to lower prices. They try to inject more competition at the marketplace, yet they have an ability to move markets solely by themselves.

So right now in a vacuum, potentially no. But when you look at the swirl of events and their M.O. kind of in the past and now, TBD.

FU: Right. And right now in fact, about 55 percent of all project searches begin on Amazon which has surpassed Google.

HUANG: Yes.

FU: That's been something that caught a lot of attention, unwanted attention on Amazon. How do you raise your company's profile, Boxed profile in this kind of environment when Amazon dominates?

HUANG: What's really interesting is that, yes, they are dominant but there's still some market share left for the rest of us especially in places like B2B. And so for us Boxed, we ship toilet paper, large-format only anywhere in the U.S. But the reality is a big part of our business is actually business-to-business.

So take for example the green rooms you have in Bloomberg or down in the beautiful atrium here, there are just hundreds of different snacks for everyone here to eat and to enjoy. Certainly the folks who stock that pantry aren't going on Amazon and clicking like SkinnyPop Chips like 400 times, you know? And so I think for us, it is really finding those niches where Amazon is not as strong and really going after it.

CHATTERLEY: You know, it's interesting, I read something that you'd said about actually some of your best customers and what you called the bread basket regions of American, populations with 50,000 people, maybe even less at times to. Just to go back to exactly to what you were saying there, do you think they're insulated from the likes of Amazon because logistically they don't really care about going to those regions?

HUANG: To a certain extent, but it -- to your guys' point before, it just offers more opportunity for folks like us because there is a quite a lot of opportunity out there, whether it's in the city or especially out in those rural areas that you mentioned because if you look at our business for example, there's 30 million folks in the U.S. that don't live within 30 minutes drive of a Costco.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

HUANG: And so those folks, it's -- whether they like Costco or not, it doesn't even matter because that brand is ubiquitous, the locations are not. And so that is how, Scarlet, to your point, that's how we've been able to grow so quickly. We went from $40,000 in sales in 2014 in my garage and last year trailing cleared over nine figures in about 36 months span. So absolutely, there is opportunity but you can't take your eye off Amazon.

FU: Chieh, you borrowed a lot from Amazon when you built out our company Boxed. What do you think you do better than Amazon now as a result? What have you adapted better at?

HUANG: It's interesting. So I feel like we have this really good ability to focus on our customer. And so our customer wants wholesale, right? And it's really difficult because Amazon is the everything store and they want to be everything for everyone. And so for us as entrepreneurs, it is really tough when you get a single person living in a 300 foot -- square foot apartment in the Upper East Side and says, you know, Boxed isn't for me. For us to really admit that it isn't for you and that it's solely for large families and for folks who want to stock up on something, that's been really difficult for us to --

FU: Interesting.

HUANG: -- concentrate on. But i feel like we do wholesale better than Amazon partly because as a wholesaler, we can sell different items and different pack sizes that Amazon usually can't get their hands on.

CHATTERLEY: You know, I want to ask you about automation. You have to be really quick because we're running out of time. But you've automated your warehouses and actually not lost any employees as a result. Is that sustainable if you scale that up?

HUANG: I think it is sustainable. I think the reality is folks will need to be able to kind of work with those robotics in order to keep those positions. So for us, we didn't go and layoff anyone solely because of automation.

CHATTERLEY: But you retrained.

HUANG: We retrain them. And now we feel like their ability to have earning power over their career is a lot better.

FU: Chieh Huang, the CEO and Founder and Boxed.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Chieh Huang discusses business.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

OCTOBER 30, 2017

SPEAKERS: CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG HOST: Now lawyers of Facebook, Google, and Twitter will appear on Capitol Hill tomorrow to answer questions about Russian meddling in the U.S. presidential election. Amazon is not part of that probe. But increasing scrutiny of the tech industry in Washington could raise antitrust questions for the e-commerce giant.

Joining us now for more insight is Chieh Huang. He is the CEO and founder of Boxed. Great to have you in New York.

CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED: Thank you for having me back.

CHATTERLEY: So what do you think about this? Do you think there needs to be more regulatory oversight of these big tech firms? We'll talk about before we dig down into your business.

HUANG: Well, it's interesting because I have real view and the view that I want to say now and then it will come and bite me in the butt later on.

(CROSSTALK)

CHATTERLEY: Tell us what you think.

HUANG: But I do think so to a certain extent, right? I think as you're looking at kind of the position of Amazon for example, the fact that they can just put a simple press release out there or file a simple trademark application and have an entire market react with billions of market cap loss, I think there's something to that. And whether that needs to be corrected by the markets in general, whether most folks in the market will eventually just say, you know, there it is more bark than bite.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

HUANG: Or whether that is a legislative action. We will see in the future.

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG HOST: Do you see any kind of evidence that a company like amazon is engaging in anti-competitive behavior?

HUANG: I don't see outside of potentially what they've done in the past with some of the acquisitions, and it's well-documented in Brad's book, "The Everything Store in terms of kind of their past acquisition practices. But in general, currently now, it's really a conundrum because what you would say is that they try to lower prices. They try to inject more competition at the marketplace, yet they have an ability to move markets solely by themselves.

So right now in a vacuum, potentially no. But when you look at the swirl of events and their M.O. kind of in the past and now, TBD.

FU: Right. And right now in fact, about 55 percent of all project searches begin on Amazon which has surpassed Google.

HUANG: Yes.

FU: That's been something that caught a lot of attention, unwanted attention on Amazon. How do you raise your company's profile, Boxed profile in this kind of environment when Amazon dominates?

HUANG: What's really interesting is that, yes, they are dominant but there's still some market share left for the rest of us especially in places like B2B. And so for us Boxed, we ship toilet paper, large-format only anywhere in the U.S. But the reality is a big part of our business is actually business-to-business.

So take for example the green rooms you have in Bloomberg or down in the beautiful atrium here, there are just hundreds of different snacks for everyone here to eat and to enjoy. Certainly the folks who stock that pantry aren't going on Amazon and clicking like SkinnyPop Chips like 400 times, you know? And so I think for us, it is really finding those niches where Amazon is not as strong and really going after it.

CHATTERLEY: You know, it's interesting, I read something that you'd said about actually some of your best customers and what you called the bread basket regions of American, populations with 50,000 people, maybe even less at times to. Just to go back to exactly to what you were saying there, do you think they're insulated from the likes of Amazon because logistically they don't really care about going to those regions?

HUANG: To a certain extent, but it -- to your guys' point before, it just offers more opportunity for folks like us because there is a quite a lot of opportunity out there, whether it's in the city or especially out in those rural areas that you mentioned because if you look at our business for example, there's 30 million folks in the U.S. that don't live within 30 minutes drive of a Costco.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

HUANG: And so those folks, it's -- whether they like Costco or not, it doesn't even matter because that brand is ubiquitous, the locations are not. And so that is how, Scarlet, to your point, that's how we've been able to grow so quickly. We went from $40,000 in sales in 2014 in my garage and last year trailing cleared over nine figures in about 36 months span. So absolutely, there is opportunity but you can't take your eye off Amazon.

FU: Chieh, you borrowed a lot from Amazon when you built out our company Boxed. What do you think you do better than Amazon now as a result? What have you adapted better at?

HUANG: It's interesting. So I feel like we have this really good ability to focus on our customer. And so our customer wants wholesale, right? And it's really difficult because Amazon is the everything store and they want to be everything for everyone. And so for us as entrepreneurs, it is really tough when you get a single person living in a 300 foot -- square foot apartment in the Upper East Side and says, you know, Boxed isn't for me. For us to really admit that it isn't for you and that it's solely for large families and for folks who want to stock up on something, that's been really difficult for us to --

FU: Interesting.

HUANG: -- concentrate on. But i feel like we do wholesale better than Amazon partly because as a wholesaler, we can sell different items and different pack sizes that Amazon usually can't get their hands on.

CHATTERLEY: You know, I want to ask you about automation. You have to be really quick because we're running out of time. But you've automated your warehouses and actually not lost any employees as a result. Is that sustainable if you scale that up?

HUANG: I think it is sustainable. I think the reality is folks will need to be able to kind of work with those robotics in order to keep those positions. So for us, we didn't go and layoff anyone solely because of automation.

CHATTERLEY: But you retrained.

HUANG: We retrain them. And now we feel like their ability to have earning power over their career is a lot better.

FU: Chieh Huang, the CEO and Founder and Boxed.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

OCTOBER 30, 2017

SPEAKERS: CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG HOST: Now lawyers of Facebook, Google, and Twitter will appear on Capitol Hill tomorrow to answer questions about Russian meddling in the U.S. presidential election. Amazon is not part of that probe. But increasing scrutiny of the tech industry in Washington could raise antitrust questions for the e-commerce giant.

Joining us now for more insight is Chieh Huang. He is the CEO and founder of Boxed. Great to have you in New York.

CHIEH HUANG, CEO, BOXED: Thank you for having me back.

CHATTERLEY: So what do you think about this? Do you think there needs to be more regulatory oversight of these big tech firms? We'll talk about before we dig down into your business.

HUANG: Well, it's interesting because I have real view and the view that I want to say now and then it will come and bite me in the butt later on.

(CROSSTALK)

CHATTERLEY: Tell us what you think.

HUANG: But I do think so to a certain extent, right? I think as you're looking at kind of the position of Amazon for example, the fact that they can just put a simple press release out there or file a simple trademark application and have an entire market react with billions of market cap loss, I think there's something to that. And whether that needs to be corrected by the markets in general, whether most folks in the market will eventually just say, you know, there it is more bark than bite.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

HUANG: Or whether that is a legislative action. We will see in the future.

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG HOST: Do you see any kind of evidence that a company like amazon is engaging in anti-competitive behavior?

HUANG: I don't see outside of potentially what they've done in the past with some of the acquisitions, and it's well-documented in Brad's book, "The Everything Store in terms of kind of their past acquisition practices. But in general, currently now, it's really a conundrum because what you would say is that they try to lower prices. They try to inject more competition at the marketplace, yet they have an ability to move markets solely by themselves.

So right now in a vacuum, potentially no. But when you look at the swirl of events and their M.O. kind of in the past and now, TBD.

FU: Right. And right now in fact, about 55 percent of all project searches begin on Amazon which has surpassed Google.

HUANG: Yes.

FU: That's been something that caught a lot of attention, unwanted attention on Amazon. How do you raise your company's profile, Boxed profile in this kind of environment when Amazon dominates?

HUANG: What's really interesting is that, yes, they are dominant but there's still some market share left for the rest of us especially in places like B2B. And so for us Boxed, we ship toilet paper, large-format only anywhere in the U.S. But the reality is a big part of our business is actually business-to-business.

So take for example the green rooms you have in Bloomberg or down in the beautiful atrium here, there are just hundreds of different snacks for everyone here to eat and to enjoy. Certainly the folks who stock that pantry aren't going on Amazon and clicking like SkinnyPop Chips like 400 times, you know? And so I think for us, it is really finding those niches where Amazon is not as strong and really going after it.

CHATTERLEY: You know, it's interesting, I read something that you'd said about actually some of your best customers and what you called the bread basket regions of American, populations with 50,000 people, maybe even less at times to. Just to go back to exactly to what you were saying there, do you think they're insulated from the likes of Amazon because logistically they don't really care about going to those regions?

HUANG: To a certain extent, but it -- to your guys' point before, it just offers more opportunity for folks like us because there is a quite a lot of opportunity out there, whether it's in the city or especially out in those rural areas that you mentioned because if you look at our business for example, there's 30 million folks in the U.S. that don't live within 30 minutes drive of a Costco.

CHATTERLEY: Yes.

HUANG: And so those folks, it's -- whether they like Costco or not, it doesn't even matter because that brand is ubiquitous, the locations are not. And so that is how, Scarlet, to your point, that's how we've been able to grow so quickly. We went from $40,000 in sales in 2014 in my garage and last year trailing cleared over nine figures in about 36 months span. So absolutely, there is opportunity but you can't take your eye off Amazon.

FU: Chieh, you borrowed a lot from Amazon when you built out our company Boxed. What do you think you do better than Amazon now as a result? What have you adapted better at?

HUANG: It's interesting. So I feel like we have this really good ability to focus on our customer. And so our customer wants wholesale, right? And it's really difficult because Amazon is the everything store and they want to be everything for everyone. And so for us as entrepreneurs, it is really tough when you get a single person living in a 300 foot -- square foot apartment in the Upper East Side and says, you know, Boxed isn't for me. For us to really admit that it isn't for you and that it's solely for large families and for folks who want to stock up on something, that's been really difficult for us to --

FU: Interesting.

HUANG: -- concentrate on. But i feel like we do wholesale better than Amazon partly because as a wholesaler, we can sell different items and different pack sizes that Amazon usually can't get their hands on.

CHATTERLEY: You know, I want to ask you about automation. You have to be really quick because we're running out of time. But you've automated your warehouses and actually not lost any employees as a result. Is that sustainable if you scale that up?

HUANG: I think it is sustainable. I think the reality is folks will need to be able to kind of work with those robotics in order to keep those positions. So for us, we didn't go and layoff anyone solely because of automation.

CHATTERLEY: But you retrained.

HUANG: We retrain them. And now we feel like their ability to have earning power over their career is a lot better.

FU: Chieh Huang, the CEO and Founder and Boxed.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5WCN-XTF1-JBG3-64WD-00000-00Child Privacy Said to Spur Investigation Of YouTube2019-06-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:59ZLexisNexisSection BColumn 0Business/Financial DeskPg. 1Child Privacy Said to Spur Investigation Of YouTubeBy DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI and CECILIA KANG

Follow Daisuke Wakabayashi and Cecilia Kang on Twitter: @daiwaka and @ceciliakang

MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. -- The Federal Trade Commission is in the advanced stages of an investigation into YouTube's handling of videos aimed at children, according to two people with knowledge of the inquiry.

The investigation, which could result in fines against YouTube, comes after complaints by parents and consumer groups that the video giant had collected data of young users.

The groups also complained that YouTube allowed harmful and adult content to appear in searches for children's content, said the two people, who were not authorized to speak about the investigation because it was private. In addition, misinformation and inappropriate content appeared in YouTube's recommendation engines, according to the complaints.

The F.T.C. is pursuing the investigation of YouTube as regulators and lawmakers in Washington are signaling their interest in curbing the power and influence of some of the biggest tech companies. The agency is poised to announce a settlement with Facebook over the social network's handling of user data and potential violations of a 2011 consent decree with the agency over previous privacy violations.

The House Judiciary Committee announced a broad antitrust investigation into Big Tech earlier this month. And the two top federal antitrust agencies, the Justice Department and the F.T.C., agreed to divide oversight over Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Google as they explore whether the companies have abused their market power to harm competition and consumers.

The F.T.C. has put more focus on child privacy. In February, the consumer protection agency fined the music video-sharing app Music.ly, now known as TikTok, a record $5.7 million for violating child privacy laws. The F.T.C. said in its settlement that TikTok allowed children under the age of 13 to use the site with little enforcement of its minimum-age requirement.

YouTube has been considering significant changes to its handling of children's videos, including how its algorithms work with the videos, according to the two people briefed on the talks. The Wall Street Journal earlier reported the internal discussions.

''We consider lots of ideas for improving YouTube, and some remain just that -- ideas. Others, we develop and launch, like our restrictions to minors live streaming or updated hate speech policy,'' Andrea Faville, a YouTube spokeswoman, said in a statement.

The Washington Post was the first to report news of the F.T.C.'s investigation of YouTube.

The federal investigation of YouTube is the latest cloud hanging over the video service, which has more than two billion users. It has come under criticism for not doing enough to filter inappropriate or dangerous content, while promoting videos that espouse extreme points of view and inconsistently applying its own rules on harassment.

YouTube's main site and app are intended for viewers 13 and older. The company directs younger children to the YouTube Kids app, which contains a filtered set of videos from the main site.

YouTube's distinction between its main product and YouTube Kids is significant because of the rules on disclosure and parental consent that kick in for sites with ''actual knowledge'' that they are trafficking in the personal information of children under 13.

But consumer advocacy groups have argued that YouTube, which is owned by Google, is able to collect data on children under 13 through its main site, where cartoons, nursery-rhyme videos and those ever-popular toy-unboxing clips garner millions of views.

Dealing with children's videos is particularly thorny for YouTube. Children are among the most avid users of YouTube, and videos geared toward them are popular on the platform. However, YouTube has struggled to keep inappropriate content away from children's videos, in part because of the volume of videos being uploaded to the platform.

In February, YouTube was rocked by a video documenting how pedophiles used the comments on videos of children to guide other predators. After brands announced plans to boycott YouTube, the company said it would disable comments on most videos featuring children under 13 years old.

Earlier this month, The New York Times published an investigation into how YouTube's automated recommendation system promoted videos of scantily clad children to people who had watched other videos of young children in compromised positions or sexually themed content.

The Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood, an advocacy group, said it had filed two complaints -- one in 2016 and another in 2018 -- with the F.T.C. about YouTube.

In 2016, the group said YouTube and other companies were using so-called influencer marketing to target children. Last year, the group was part of a coalition of children's advocacy groups that filed a complaint saying YouTube was collecting the personal information of children under 13 without obtaining parental consent.

''Action by the F.T.C. is long overdue,'' said David Monahan, campaign manager at the Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood. ''If action is coming, we hope it comes with the conditions that YouTube clean up its act and stop targeting children.''

With skepticism toward the tech industry growing in Washington, the F.T.C. investigation is likely to be applauded by lawmakers. Senator Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts and a frequent YouTube critic, welcomed the inquiry. In March, Mr. Markey and Senator Josh Hawley, Republican of Missouri, introduced a bill that would apply the children's online privacy law to teenagers up to 16.

''It is no secret that kids flock to YouTube every day, but the company has yet to take the necessary steps to protect its youngest users,'' Mr. Markey said in a statement. ''I am pleased to see reports that the F.T.C. is working to hold YouTube accountable for its actions.''

urn:contentItem:5WD4-6YG1-DY91-K3B5-00000-00Child privacy said to spur investigation of YouTube;Probe comes after complaints video giant had collected data of young users2019-06-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:59ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B5Child privacy said to spur investigation of YouTubeProbe comes after complaints video giant had collected data of young usersDaisuke Wakabayashi and Cecilia Kang The New York TimesMOUNTAIN VIEW, CALIF.

The U.S. Federal Trade Commission is in the advanced stages of an investigation into YouTube's handling of videos aimed at children, according to two people with knowledge of the inquiry.

The investigation, which could result in fines against YouTube, comes after complaints by parents and consumer groups that the video giant had collected data of young users.

The groups also complained that YouTube allowed harmful and adult content to appear in searches for children's content, said the two people, who were not authorized to speak about the investigation because it was private. In addition, misinformation and inappropriate content appeared in YouTube's recommendation engines, according to the complaints.

The FTC is pursuing the investigation of YouTube as regulators and lawmakers in Washington are signalling their interest in curbing the power and influence of some of the biggest tech companies. The agency is poised to announce a settlement with Facebook over the social network's handling of user data and potential violations of a 2011 consent decree with the agency over previous privacy violations.

The House Judiciary Committee announced a broad antitrust investigation into Big Tech earlier this month. And the two top federal antitrust agencies, the Justice Department and the FTC, agreed to divide oversight over Apple, Amazon, Facebook and Google as they explore whether the companies have abused their market power to harm competition and consumers.

The FTC has put more focus on child privacy. In February, the consumer protection agency fined the music video-sharing app Music.ly, now known as TikTok, a record $5.7 million (U.S.) for violating child privacy laws. The FTC said in its settlement that TikTok allowed children under the age of 13 to use the site with little enforcement of its minimum-age requirement.

YouTube has been considering significant changes to its handling of children's videos, including how its algorithms work with the videos, according to the two people briefed on the talks. The Wall Street Journal earlier reported the internal discussions.

"We consider lots of ideas for improving YouTube and some remain just that - ideas. Others, we develop and launch, like our restrictions to minors livestreaming or updated hate speech policy," Andrea Faville, a YouTube spokesperson, said in a statement.

The Washington Post was the first to report news of the FTC's investigation of YouTube.

The federal investigation of YouTube is the latest cloud hanging over the video service, which has more than 2 billion users. It has come under criticism for not doing enough to filter inappropriate or dangerous content, while promoting videos that espouse extreme points of view and inconsistently applying its own rules on harassment.

YouTube's main site and app are intended for viewers 13 and older. The company directs younger children to the YouTube Kids app, which contains a filtered set of videos from the main site.

YouTube's distinction between its main product and YouTube Kids is significant because of the rules on disclosure and parental consent that kick in for sites with "actual knowledge" that they are trafficking in the personal information of children younger than 13.

But consumer advocacy groups have argued that YouTube, which is owned by Google, is able to collect data on children under 13 through its main site, where cartoons, nursery-rhyme videos and those ever-popular toy-unboxing clips garner millions of views.

Dealing with children's videos is particularly thorny for YouTube. Children are among the most avid users of YouTube and videos geared toward them are popular on the platform.

However, YouTube has struggled to keep inappropriate content away from children's videos, in part because of the volume of videos being uploaded to the platform.

urn:contentItem:5Y5T-1T01-F0JC-M4WM-00000-00Children's charity calls for online watchdog to tackle child abuse2020-02-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:59ZLexisNexisChildren's charity calls for online watchdog to tackle child abuseGraeme Hetherington

A NATIONAL children's charity is calling on the government to tackle the growing problem of online child abuse.

The NSPCC is calling on people to email their MP urging them to back a new Bill that paves the way for a proper independent watchdog to regulate online harms against children.

The plea came after a Darlington man was given a suspended sentence at Teesside Crown Court for attempting to groom a young girl, who was in fact an adult woman.

A group of paedophile hunters tracked down Ian David Smith to the warehouse he worked in after he sent a picture of his genitals to a girl he believed to be 12-years-old.

Pervert caught by online paedophile hunters after sending a picture of his genitals to 'girl'

Smith, of Station Road, Middleton St George, near Darlington, pleaded guilty to three charges; possessing indecent images of children, distributing indecent images of children and engaging in sexual communication with a child.

A spokesperson for the charity called on people to get their local MP involved in calling for a crackdown on online platforms used to share child abuse images or for people to groom young children.

They said: "This is yet another disturbing reminder of the way predators seek out potential young victims using online platforms.

"The onus is on the Government to act swiftly and bring in a regulator which will force big tech to do much more to protect children online - with tough sanctions if they fail to deliver."

Man with stash of child abuse images, of victims as young as 7, avoids jail

Other cases dealt with in the same court this year alone include Ian Whiting who was caught with thousands of indecent images when the internet provider address he was 'piggy-backing' on was used to access illegal content.

The 33-year-old, now of Bedlington but formerly of Coulby Newham, Middlesbrough, pleaded guilty to three charges of making indecent images with 14 of the most serious category A images, 36 category B and 7,405 images in category C. He also pleaded guilty a charge of possessing 16 extreme pornography images.

Whiting was sentenced to eight months in custody for the most serious of offence - making the Category A images - but suspended it for two years.

Judge slams 'distorted proclivities' of sex offender

Stewart Tivendale, of The Crescent, Middlesbrough, downloaded child sex abuse videos and pictures within 24 hours of being released from prison.

The 24-year-old was sentenced for an extended period of five years as he had already served three years in custody for his previous offences in 2018.

urn:contentItem:5WJC-B3W1-F19Y-C355-00000-00Children's privacy advocates call out big tech for lax attitude toward safety2019-07-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:00ZLexisNexisExtraChildren's privacy advocates call out big tech for lax attitude toward safetyAnna Akins

Child privacy advocates testifying on Capitol Hill said companies such as Facebook, Google and Snap should do more to ensure children's online safety. They also urged federal lawmakers to press for proper enforcement of children's legal protections.

Child privacy advocates called out companies such as Facebook Inc., Google LLC and Snap Inc., the parent of video-messaging app Snapchat, for a lax attitude toward safeguarding children online and pressed federal lawmakers to ensure proper enforcement of children's legal protections.

In a July 9 Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, representatives of the various children's education and advocacy groups offered a variety of solutions, from a new rating system for apps popular with children and teens to better enforcement of federal laws designed to protect children. Lawmakers from both major political parties seemed to agree that tech companies need to do more to help protect children from exploitative and mature online content.

No technology company representatives testified at the hearing, though a nonprofit group whose members include several big tech names such as Facebook, Google and Snap was part of the panel of witnesses. That group, the Family Online Safety Institute, advocated for more education of parents and children about navigating online content, as well as broader adoption of existing parental control software.

Christopher McKenna, founder and CEO of Protect Young Eyes, an organization that aims to educate families, schools and churches about online safety, proposed the creation of a new independent rating system for popular social media applications to better educate parents about the various risks associated with those sites, particularly the risk of being exposed to sexually explicit content. He said existing ratings fail to warn parents about the rampant sexual images and activity accessible on many popular social media platforms.

"Tech companies will tell us that ratings are already in place; however, ratings are not uniform, lack transparency, and there's little accountability for inaccurate ratings," McKenna said in written testimony.

Angela Campbell, a law professor at Georgetown University and co-director of Georgetown's Institute for Public Representation, said laws regarding children's online privacy have not kept pace with the growth and evolution of internet platforms. As such, big tech has felt "empowered to ignore the existing safeguards," Campbell said.

She urged the committee to place more pressure not only on tech companies but also the U.S. Federal Trade Commission to enforce laws such as the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) of 1998, which restricts websites from collecting information on children under the age of 13 without obtaining consent from their parents.

Google-owned YouTube has faced increased scrutiny from regulators and consumers this year over its handling of a range of issues involving children's content, including algorithm-driven viewing suggestions, advertising and video comments. YouTube reportedly has weighed creating a separate platform for children's content, though Bloomberg News recently reported that regulators were considering allowing the platform to disable advertising on certain children's channels as an alternative.

"The task of protecting children online is nearly impossible without the partnership of the big tech companies," said Sen. Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn., who chastised companies for "inadequate and abysmally slow" responses to questions and concerns about how they handle children's sensitive online data.

Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Mo., went further, accusing YouTube in particular of prioritizing ad revenue streams over safety. "I think we can agree that exploiting children online is one of the worst dangers and one of the worst social threats that we face," Hawley said. His concern is that tech companies have prioritized ensuring the reach of revenue-driving video recommendation services over safety.

Hawley in June introduced a bill that would ban video-hosting websites from including most videos featuring minors in their recommendation engines, though the videos could still appear in search. The bill is pending a review by the Judiciary committee.

urn:contentItem:5VJV-1GF1-JCW9-24RN-00000-00Children's Rights Alliance welcome new online safety laws2019-03-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:34:00ZLexisNexisIRISH NEWSChildren's Rights Alliance welcome new online safety laws

The Children's Rights Alliance is welcoming new laws aimed at improving online safety.

The Communications Minister will announce plans to establish an Online Safety Commissioner, which will have a number of powers.

It will examine and certify whether the safety standards a company has in place are good enough.

The Commissioner will also act as an appeals body.

Tanya Ward, Chief Executive of the Children's Rights Alliance, says the new law will focus on digital service providers:

"We are very much in favour of it (the new legislation)," she said.

"To date the digital world, the online world has become a wild west where there has been no regulation or poor regulation of big tech companies.

[readmore]908513[/readmore]

"A lot of the focus has been on educating parents and educating children or young people on how to be safe in the online world.

"But we have really taken the focus off service providers."
